molecular.simulations.temp_schedule¶

molecular.simulations.temp_schedule(temp_min=300, temp_max=440, n_temps=40, mode='geometric')[source]¶

Create a temperature schedule that could be used, for instance, with replica exchange.

There are several choices for mode. Note that \(T\) refers to the temperature at \(i = 1 ... R\), where \(T_1\) is temp_min and \(T_R\) is temp_max. In total, there are \(R\) temperatures (= n_temps).

  • “geometric” 1

\[T_i = T_1 \left( \frac{T_R}{T_1} \right)^{\frac{i-1}{R-1}}\]

  • “linear”

\[T_i = T_1 + (i-1) \frac{T_R-T_1}{R-1}\]

  • “parabolic” (Note if n_temps is even, temp_max won’t directly be sampled).

\[T_i = T_1 - \frac{T_R-T_1}{\left( \frac{R-1}{2} \right) ^2} (i-1) (i-R)\]
Parameters

  • temp_min (float) – Lowest temperature

  • temp_max (float) – Highest temperature

  • n_temps (int) – Number of temperatures

  • mode (str) – Mode to produce schedule. Valid options include “geometric”, “linear”, “parabolic”. Any substring will match, but the preference should be to use the full option label. (Default: “geometric”)

Returns

Temperature schedule

Return type

numpy.ndarray

Examples

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import molecular as mol

n_temps = 10
geometric = mol.temp_schedule(300, 440, n_temps, 'geometric')
linear = mol.temp_schedule(300, 440, n_temps, 'linear')
parabolic = mol.temp_schedule(300, 440, n_temps, 'parabolic')

plt.figure()
plt.plot(range(n_temps), geometric, label='geometric')
plt.plot(range(n_temps), linear, label='linear')
plt.plot(range(n_temps), parabolic, label='parabolic')
plt.xlabel('index')
plt.ylabel('temperature')
plt.legend(loc='center left', bbox_to_anchor=(1, 0.5))
plt.show()
